questions.text: What is the primary role of paramedics???
questions.explanation: Paramedics primarily provide emergency medical care to patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate action in dealing with home delivery complicated with cord prolapse?
options: Ask the patient to push hard
Try to reduce the prolapsed cord then transfer the patient
Give the patient one dose of midazolam then transfer the patient
Elevate the presenting fetal part to reduce the compression on the cord

questions.text: Which vital sign is most critical in assessing shock?
questions.explanation: Blood pressure helps assess perfusion and the severity of shock.

questions.text: What is the first step in managing an unresponsive patient?
questions.explanation: Opening the airway ensures the patient can breathe.

questions.text: Which structure is responsible for oxygen exchange in the lungs?
questions.explanation: Alveoli are the primary site of gas exchange in the lungs.

questions.text: What does SAMPLE history stand for?
options: Signs, Allergies, Medications, Past history, Last meal, Events
Symptoms, Age, Medications, Past illnesses, Last intake, Events
Signs, Allergies, Medications, Past illnesses, Last oral intake, Events
Symptoms, Allergies, Medications, Past history, Last oral intake, Events
questions.explanation: SAMPLE is a mnemonic for patient history assessment.

questions.text: Which rhythm is shockable in cardiac arrest?
questions.explanation: Ventricular fibrillation is one of the shockable rhythms.

questions.text: What medication is commonly used in anaphylaxis?
questions.explanation: Epinephrine is the first-line treatment in anaphylaxis.

questions.text: What is the normal respiratory rate for an adult?
questions.explanation: The normal adult respiratory rate is 12–20 breaths per minute.

questions.text: How should you treat a sucking chest wound?
options: Use an occlusive dressing taped on three sides
Leave it open to allow drainage
questions.explanation: An occlusive dressing taped on three sides creates a flutter valve effect.

questions.text: What is the preferred method of delivering oxygen to a conscious hypoxic patient?
questions.explanation: A non-rebreather mask delivers high-flow oxygen to conscious patients.

questions.text: What is a contraindication for nitroglycerin administration?
questions.explanation: Nitroglycerin is contraindicated with recent use of ED drugs due to risk of severe hypotension.

questions.text: What is the Glasgow Coma Scale used to assess?
questions.explanation: The GCS evaluates eye, verbal, and motor responses to assess consciousness.

questions.text: Which sign is most indicative of a tension pneumothorax?
questions.explanation: Tracheal deviation away from the affected side is a key sign of tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the lower airway?
questions.explanation: The trachea is a component of the lower airway.

questions.text: What does the 'P' in OPQRST stand for?
questions.explanation: 'P' refers to what provokes or worsens the pain.

questions.text: What is the appropriate depth of chest compressions in an adult?
questions.explanation: Adult chest compressions should be at least 2 inches deep.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign of hypoglycemia?
questions.explanation: Confusion is a common neurological sign of low blood sugar.

questions.text: What does AED stand for?
questions.explanation: AED is a life-saving device for treating sudden cardiac arrest.

questions.text: When should you reassess a stable patient?
questions.explanation: Stable patients are reassessed every 15 minutes.

questions.text: What does DCAP-BTLS stand for?
options: Deformities, Contusions, Abrasions, Punctures, Burns, Tenderness, Lacerations, Swelling
Deformities, Cuts, Aches, Punctures, Bleeding, Tension, Lumps, Sensitivity
Decompression, Circulation, Airway, Pain, Breathing, Temperature, Loss of sensation, Skin tone
Drainage, Contusions, Abdomen, Pulse, Bruising, Thirst, Lesions, Stiffness
questions.explanation: DCAP-BTLS is a trauma assessment mnemonic.

questions.text: Which of the following requires immediate transport?
questions.explanation: An unconscious diabetic patient requires urgent care.

questions.text: What is the best method to open the airway of a patient with suspected spinal injury?
questions.explanation: Jaw-thrust protects the cervical spine.

questions.text: How many compressions per minute should be performed during CPR?
questions.explanation: The recommended rate is 100–120 compressions per minute.

questions.text: Which organ is located in the right upper quadrant?
questions.explanation: The liver is located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen.
